intro: Oenothera rubrinervoides, commonly known as the red-veined evening primrose, is a species of flowering plant in the Onagraceae family. It is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. The plant produces showy yellow to orange flowers that open in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped with prominent red veins, giving it its common name. The plant is known for its ability to survive in poor soil conditions and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats.
